01-01: On this day in 1863, Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation, declaring slaves in Confederate states to be free.
01-02: In 1974, the Maximum Speed Limit in the United States was lowered to 55 MPH to conserve gasoline during an OPEC embargo.
01-03: In 1959, Alaska was admitted as the 49th U.S. state.
01-04: In 2004, NASA's Spirit rover successfully landed on Mars.
01-05: In 1933, construction began on the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.
01-06: In 1912, New Mexico was admitted as the 47th U.S. state.
01-07: In 1610, Galileo Galilei observed four of Jupiter's moons for the first time.
01-08: In 1815, the Battle of New Orleans was fought, a decisive American victory in the War of 1812.
01-09: In 2007, Apple CEO Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone.
01-10: In 1920, the League of Nations was officially established.
01-11: In 1964, the U.S. Surgeon General released the first report linking smoking to cancer.
01-12: In 1908, a long-distance radio message was sent from the Eiffel Tower for the first time.
01-13: In 1990, Douglas Wilder became the first elected African American governor in the U.S. (Virginia).
01-14: In 1784, the Continental Congress ratified the Treaty of Paris, officially ending the American Revolutionary War.
01-15: In 2001, Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia, was launched.
01-16: In 1920, Prohibition began in the United States with the 18th Amendment.
01-17: In 1706, Benjamin Franklin, one of America's Founding Fathers, was born in Boston.
01-18: In 1778, Captain James Cook became the first European to discover the Hawaiian Islands.
01-19: In 1809, author and poet Edgar Allan Poe was born in Boston.
01-20: In 1937, Franklin D. Roosevelt was the first U.S. President inaugurated on this date.
01-21: In 1976, the Concorde supersonic transport jet began its first commercial flights.
01-22: In 1973, the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision legalized abortion nationwide.
01-23: In 1849, Elizabeth Blackwell was awarded her M.D. by the Geneva Medical College, becoming the first female doctor in the U.S.
01-24: In 1848, gold was discovered at Sutter's Mill in California, sparking the Gold Rush.
01-25: In 1924, the first Winter Olympic Games were held in Chamonix, France.
01-26: In 1788, the British First Fleet, led by Captain Arthur Phillip, landed at Sydney Cove to establish a penal colony.
01-27: In 1945, Soviet troops liberated the Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland.
01-28: In 1986, the Space Shuttle Challenger broke apart 73 seconds after liftoff, killing all seven astronauts.
01-29: In 1861, Kansas was admitted as the 34th U.S. state.
01-30: In 1933, Adolf Hitler was appointed Chancellor of Germany.
01-31: In 1958, the United States launched its first satellite, Explorer 1.
02-01: In 1865, President Abraham Lincoln approved the 13th Amendment, abolishing slavery.
02-02: In 1887, the first Groundhog Day was celebrated in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania.
02-03: In 1870, the 15th Amendment was ratified, granting African American men the right to vote.
02-04: In 2004, Mark Zuckerberg launched Facebook from his Harvard dorm room.
02-05: In 1917, the current constitution of Mexico was adopted.
02-06: In 1952, Elizabeth II became Queen of the United Kingdom upon the death of her father, George VI.
02-07: In 1964, The Beatles arrived in the United States for the first time, kicking off the 'British Invasion'.
02-08: In 1587, Mary, Queen of Scots, was executed at Fotheringhay Castle.
02-09: In 1969, the Boeing 747, the first 'jumbo jet', made its maiden flight.
02-10: In 1996, the IBM supercomputer Deep Blue defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov for the first time.
02-11: In 1990, Nelson Mandela was released from prison in South Africa after 27 years.
02-12: In 1809, Abraham Lincoln, the 16th U.S. President, was born in Kentucky.
02-13: In 1633, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei arrived in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
02-14: In 1929, the St. Valentine's Day Massacre occurred in Chicago, a key event in the rise of Al Capone.
02-15: In 1965, the current red-and-white maple leaf flag was adopted as the national flag of Canada.
02-16: In 1923, Howard Carter unsealed the burial chamber of Pharaoh Tutankhamun.
02-17: In 1933, Newsweek magazine was published for the first time.
02-18: In 1930, Pluto was discovered by astronomer Clyde Tombaugh at the Lowell Observatory.
02-19: In 1945, U.S. Marines landed on Iwo Jima during World War II.
02-20: In 1962, John Glenn became the first American to orbit the Earth.
02-21: In 1848, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels published 'The Communist Manifesto'.
02-22: In 1732, George Washington, the first U.S. President, was born in Virginia.
02-23: In 1945, U.S. Marines raised the American flag on Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima.
02-24: In 1582, Pope Gregory XIII announced the Gregorian calendar.
02-25: In 1964, Muhammad Ali (then Cassius Clay) defeated Sonny Liston to become the heavyweight boxing champion.
02-26: In 1993, a bomb exploded in the parking garage of the World Trade Center in New York City.
02-27: In 1827, the first Mardi Gras celebration was held in New Orleans.
02-28: In 1991, the first Gulf War ended after a ceasefire was declared.
02-29: On this leap day in 1504, Christopher Columbus used his knowledge of a lunar eclipse to frighten hostile natives in Jamaica into providing supplies.
03-01: In 1961, President John F. Kennedy established the Peace Corps.
03-02: In 1965, the film 'The Sound of Music' premiered in New York City.
03-03: In 1931, 'The Star-Spangled Banner' was officially adopted as the U.S. national anthem.
03-04: In 1789, the first U.S. Congress met and the Constitution went into effect.
03-05: In 1770, the Boston Massacre occurred, a key event leading to the American Revolution.
03-06: In 1836, the Battle of the Alamo ended after a 13-day siege by Mexican forces.
03-07: In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was granted a patent for the telephone.
03-08: The first International Women's Day was observed in 1911.
03-09: In 1959, the Barbie doll was unveiled at the American International Toy Fair.
03-10: In 1862, the United States issued its first paper money.
03-11: In 2020, the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic.
03-12: In 1930, Mahatma Gandhi began the Salt March, a major act of nonviolent civil disobedience.
03-13: In 1781, William Herschel discovered the planet Uranus.
03-14: In 1794, Eli Whitney was granted a patent for the cotton gin.
03-15: In 44 BC, Julius Caesar was assassinated in the Roman Senate by a group of conspirators.
03-16: In 1802, the United States Military Academy at West Point was established.
03-17: In 1762, the first St. Patrick's Day parade was held in New York City.
03-18: In 1965, cosmonaut Alexei Leonov performed the first spacewalk.
03-19: In 1931, gambling was legalized in Nevada.
03-20: In 1852, Harriet Beecher Stowe's influential anti-slavery novel 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' was published.
03-21: In 1963, the Alcatraz federal penitentiary in San Francisco Bay was closed.
03-22: In 1993, Intel shipped the first Pentium chips.
03-23: In 1775, Patrick Henry delivered his famous 'Give me liberty, or give me death!' speech.
03-24: In 1882, Robert Koch announced the discovery of the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis.
03-25: In 1911, the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in New York City led to major factory safety reforms.
03-26: In 1953, Dr. Jonas Salk announced he had developed a polio vaccine.
03-27: In 1912, Washington D.C.'s famous cherry trees, a gift from Japan, were planted.
03-28: In 1979, a partial meltdown of the Unit 2 reactor at Three Mile Island nuclear power plant occurred.
03-29: In 1886, Dr. John Pemberton brewed the first batch of Coca-Cola in Atlanta.
03-30: In 1867, the United States purchased Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million.
03-31: In 1889, the Eiffel Tower was officially opened in Paris.
04-01: In 1976, Apple Inc. was founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne.
04-02: In 1513, Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de León first sighted Florida.
04-03: In 1973, the first handheld mobile phone call was made by Martin Cooper of Motorola.
04-04: In 1968, civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis.
04-05: In 1614, Pocahontas married English colonist John Rolfe in Virginia.
04-06: In 1896, the first modern Olympic Games opened in Athens, Greece.
04-07: In 1948, the World Health Organization (WHO) was established.
04-08: In 1974, Hank Aaron hit his 715th home run, breaking Babe Ruth's long-standing record.
04-09: In 1865, Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered to Union General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House, ending the Civil War.
04-10: In 1912, the RMS Titanic set sail from Southampton, England, on its maiden voyage.
04-11: In 1970, the Apollo 13 mission launched from Kennedy Space Center.
04-12: In 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first human to travel into space.
04-13: In 1743, Thomas Jefferson, the third U.S. President, was born in Virginia.
04-14: In 1865, U.S. President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated at Ford's Theatre in Washington D.C.
04-15: In 1912, the RMS Titanic sank in the North Atlantic Ocean after hitting an iceberg.
04-16: In 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. wrote his 'Letter from Birmingham Jail'.
04-17: In 1964, the Ford Mustang was first introduced to the public.
04-18: In 1775, Paul Revere made his famous midnight ride to warn colonists of the approaching British forces.
04-19: In 1775, the American Revolutionary War began with the battles of Lexington and Concord.
04-20: In 1902, Marie and Pierre Curie isolated the radioactive element radium.
04-21: According to legend, Rome was founded on this day in 753 BC.
04-22: The first Earth Day was celebrated in 1970.
04-23: In 1616, both William Shakespeare and Miguel de Cervantes, two of the world's greatest writers, died.
04-24: In 1800, the U.S. Library of Congress was established.
04-25: In 1953, Francis Crick and James Watson published their discovery of the double helix structure of DNA.
04-26: In 1986, the world's worst nuclear disaster occurred at the Chernobyl power plant in Ukraine.
04-27: In 1810, Ludwig van Beethoven composed his famous piano piece, 'Für Elise'.
04-28: In 1945, Italian dictator Benito Mussolini was executed by partisans.
04-29: In 1429, Joan of Arc arrived to relieve the Siege of Orléans.
04-30: In 1789, George Washington was inaugurated as the first President of the United States.
05-01: In 1931, the Empire State Building opened in New York City.
05-02: In 1519, Leonardo da Vinci, the renowned artist and inventor, died in France.
05-03: In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
05-04: In 1970, four students were killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University during a Vietnam War protest.
05-05: In 1821, Napoleon Bonaparte died in exile on the island of Saint Helena.
05-06: In 1937, the German airship Hindenburg burst into flames while attempting to land in New Jersey.
05-07: In 1915, a German submarine sank the British passenger liner RMS Lusitania, a key event in turning public opinion against Germany.
05-08: In 1945, V-E Day (Victory in Europe Day) was celebrated, marking the end of World War II in Europe.
05-09: In 1960, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first commercially produced birth control pill.
05-10: In 1869, the First Transcontinental Railroad in North America was completed at Promontory Summit, Utah.
05-11: In 330, Constantine the Great dedicated Constantinople as the new capital of the Roman Empire.
05-12: In 1820, Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, was born in Florence, Italy.
05-13: In 1607, English colonists established their first permanent settlement in North America at Jamestown, Virginia.
05-14: In 1796, Edward Jenner administered the first smallpox vaccination.
05-15: In 1940, the first McDonald's restaurant was opened in San Bernardino, California, by Richard and Maurice McDonald.
05-16: In 1929, the first Academy Awards ceremony was held in Hollywood.
05-17: In 1954, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional.
05-18: In 1980, Mount St. Helens erupted in Washington state, causing widespread devastation.
05-19: In 1536, Anne Boleyn, the second wife of King Henry VIII of England, was executed.
05-20: In 1927, Charles Lindbergh took off from New York for the first solo, non-stop transatlantic flight.
05-21: In 1881, the American Red Cross was founded by Clara Barton.
05-22: In 1906, the Wright brothers were granted a patent for their 'flying machine'.
05-23: In 1701, Captain William Kidd was hanged in London for piracy and murder.
05-24: In 1844, Samuel Morse sent the first public telegraph message, 'What hath God wrought'.
05-25: In 1977, the first 'Star Wars' film (Episode IV: A New Hope) was released.
05-26: In 1897, Bram Stoker's gothic horror novel 'Dracula' was published.
05-27: In 1937, the Golden Gate Bridge opened to pedestrian traffic.
05-28: In 1934, the Dionne quintuplets, the first known to survive infancy, were born in Ontario, Canada.
05-29: In 1953, Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay of Nepal became the first people to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
05-30: In 1431, Joan of Arc was burned at the stake in Rouen, France.
05-31: In 1889, the disastrous Johnstown Flood occurred in Pennsylvania, killing over 2,200 people.
06-01: In 1980, CNN (Cable News Network), the first 24-hour news channel, was launched.
06-02: In 1953, the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II took place in Westminster Abbey, London.
06-03: In 1965, Ed White became the first American to perform a spacewalk.
06-04: In 1989, the Tiananmen Square protests were violently suppressed in Beijing, China.
06-05: In 1968, U.S. Senator and presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in Los Angeles.
06-06: In 1944, D-Day, the Allied invasion of Normandy, began during World War II.
06-07: In 1975, Sony introduced the Betamax videocassette recorder.
06-08: In 1949, George Orwell's dystopian novel 'Nineteen Eighty-Four' was published.
06-09: In 68 AD, Roman Emperor Nero committed suicide.
06-10: In 1752, Benjamin Franklin is said to have flown a kite in a thunderstorm to prove that lightning is electricity.
06-11: In 1776, the Continental Congress appointed a committee to draft the Declaration of Independence.
06-12: In 1963, civil rights activist Medgar Evers was assassinated in Mississippi.
06-13: In 323 BC, Alexander the Great died in Babylon at the age of 32.
06-14: In 1777, the Continental Congress adopted the Stars and Stripes as the national flag of the United States.
06-15: In 1215, King John of England was forced to sign the Magna Carta, a foundational document for constitutional law.
06-16: In 1963, Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman to travel into space.
06-17: In 1972, the Watergate scandal began with the arrest of five men for breaking into the Democratic National Committee headquarters.
06-18: In 1815, Napoleon Bonaparte was defeated at the Battle of Waterloo.
06-19: In 1865, Union soldiers brought the news of freedom to enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, an event now celebrated as Juneteenth.
06-20: In 1782, the U.S. Congress adopted the Great Seal of the United States.
06-21: In 1982, Prince William, second in line to the British throne, was born.
06-22: In 1941, Germany launched Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union.
06-23: In 1868, Christopher Latham Sholes was granted a patent for the typewriter.
06-24: In 1497, John Cabot landed in North America, claiming the land for England.
06-25: In 1876, the Battle of the Little Bighorn took place, where Lt. Col. George Custer's forces were defeated.
06-26: In 1945, the charter of the United Nations was signed in San Francisco.
06-27: In 1950, the United States decided to send troops to fight in the Korean War.
06-28: In 1914, the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary in Sarajevo triggered the start of World War I.
06-29: In 2007, the first Apple iPhone went on sale.
06-30: In 1908, the Tunguska event, a massive explosion believed to be caused by a meteoroid, occurred in Siberia.
07-01: In 1863, the Battle of Gettysburg, a turning point in the American Civil War, began.
07-02: In 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act into law.
07-03: In 1863, Pickett's Charge, a major Confederate assault, was repulsed at the Battle of Gettysburg.
07-04: In 1776, the U.S. Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Second Continental Congress.
07-05: In 1996, Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be cloned from an adult cell, was born.
07-06: In 1885, Louis Pasteur successfully tested his rabies vaccine on a young boy.
07-07: In 2005, a series of coordinated terrorist bombings struck London's public transport system.
07-08: In 1776, the Liberty Bell rang out from the Pennsylvania State House (now Independence Hall) to summon citizens for the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence.
07-09: In 1868, the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was ratified, granting citizenship to all persons born or naturalized in the U.S.
07-10: In 1962, Telstar, the world's first active communications satellite, was launched.
07-11: In 1804, U.S. Vice President Aaron Burr fatally shot his political rival, Alexander Hamilton, in a duel.
07-12: In 100 BC, Julius Caesar, the Roman general and statesman, was born.
07-13: In 1985, the Live Aid benefit concerts for famine relief were held in London and Philadelphia.
07-14: In 1789, citizens of Paris stormed the Bastille, a pivotal event in the French Revolution.
07-15: In 1806, Zebulon Pike began his expedition to explore the American West.
07-16: In 1945, the first atomic bomb was successfully detonated in the Trinity test in New Mexico.
07-17: In 1955, Disneyland opened in Anaheim, California.
07-18: In 64 AD, the Great Fire of Rome began, which Emperor Nero was famously accused of starting.
07-19: In 1848, the first women's rights convention in the United States was held in Seneca Falls, New York.
07-20: In 1969, Neil Armstrong became the first person to walk on the Moon.
07-21: In 1861, the First Battle of Bull Run, the first major battle of the American Civil War, was fought.
07-22: In 1934, notorious bank robber John Dillinger was killed by FBI agents in Chicago.
07-23: In 1903, the Ford Motor Company sold its first car, the Model A.
07-24: In 1911, explorer Hiram Bingham III rediscovered the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu.
07-25: In 1978, Louise Brown, the world's first 'test-tube baby', was born in England.
07-26: In 1953, Fidel Castro led an unsuccessful attack on the Moncada Barracks, beginning the Cuban Revolution.
07-27: In 1953, the Korean War Armistice Agreement was signed, ending the fighting.
07-28: In 1914, World War I began as Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia.
07-29: In 1958, President Dwight D. Eisenhower signed the act that created NASA.
07-30: In 1975, former Teamsters union president Jimmy Hoffa disappeared and was never found.
07-31: In 1790, the first U.S. patent was issued to Samuel Hopkins for a new method of making potash.
08-01: In 1790, the first United States Census was conducted.
08-02: In 1776, most of the delegates to the Second Continental Congress signed the U.S. Declaration of Independence.
08-03: In 1492, Christopher Columbus set sail from Palos, Spain, on his first voyage to the New World.
08-04: In 1944, Anne Frank and her family were arrested by the Gestapo in Amsterdam.
08-05: In 1962, actress Marilyn Monroe was found dead in her home.
08-06: In 1945, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan.
08-07: In 1782, George Washington created the Badge of Military Merit, the forerunner of the Purple Heart.
08-08: In 1974, Richard Nixon announced his resignation as President of the United States.
08-09: In 1945, the United States dropped a second atomic bomb on Nagasaki, Japan.
08-10: In 1792, during the French Revolution, the Tuileries Palace was stormed and King Louis XVI was arrested.
08-11: In 1934, the first federal prisoners arrived at the Alcatraz island prison.
08-12: In 1981, IBM introduced its first Personal Computer (PC).
08-13: In 1961, East Germany began construction of the Berlin Wall.
08-14: In 1945, Japan agreed to an unconditional surrender, effectively ending World War II (V-J Day).
08-15: In 1947, India gained independence from British rule.
08-16: In 1896, gold was discovered in the Klondike region of the Yukon, sparking the Klondike Gold Rush.
08-17: In 1978, the first successful transatlantic balloon flight was completed.
08-18: In 1920, the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was ratified, granting women the right to vote.
08-19: In 1812, the USS Constitution defeated the HMS Guerriere, earning the nickname 'Old Ironsides'.
08-20: In 1940, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill delivered his famous 'Never was so much owed by so many to so few' speech.
08-21: In 1959, Hawaii was admitted as the 50th U.S. state.
08-22: In 1485, the Battle of Bosworth Field was fought, ending the Wars of the Roses in England.
08-23: In 79 AD, Mount Vesuvius began to erupt, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum.
08-24: In 1814, British forces captured Washington D.C. and burned the White House and Capitol.
08-25: In 1916, the National Park Service was established in the United States.
08-26: In 1920, the 19th Amendment, guaranteeing women's suffrage, was certified.
08-27: In 1883, the volcanic island of Krakatoa erupted, creating one of the largest explosions in recorded history.
08-28: In 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his 'I Have a Dream' speech during the March on Washington.
08-29: In 2005, Hurricane Katrina made landfall on the U.S. Gulf Coast, causing catastrophic damage.
08-30: In 1967, Thurgood Marshall was confirmed as the first African American Supreme Court Justice.
08-31: In 1997, Diana, Princess of Wales, was killed in a car crash in Paris.
09-01: In 1939, Germany invaded Poland, beginning World War II in Europe.
09-02: In 1945, Japan formally surrendered aboard the USS Missouri, officially ending World War II.
09-03: In 1783, the Treaty of Paris was signed, officially ending the American Revolutionary War.
09-04: In 1888, George Eastman registered the trademark 'Kodak' and received a patent for his camera that used roll film.
09-05: In 1972, the Munich massacre occurred, where Palestinian terrorists took members of the Israeli Olympic team hostage.
09-06: In 1522, one of Ferdinand Magellan's surviving ships completed the first circumnavigation of the Earth.
09-07: In 1822, Brazil declared its independence from Portugal.
09-08: In 1900, the Great Galveston Hurricane, the deadliest natural disaster in U.S. history, made landfall.
09-09: In 1850, California was admitted as the 31st U.S. state.
09-10: In 1846, Elias Howe was granted a patent for the sewing machine.
09-11: In 2001, terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon occurred.
09-12: In 1953, John F. Kennedy married Jacqueline Bouvier.
09-13: In 1814, Francis Scott Key was inspired to write the poem 'The Defence of Fort McHenry', which later became 'The Star-Spangled Banner'.
09-14: In 1752, the British Empire adopted the Gregorian calendar, skipping 11 days.
09-15: In 1935, the Nuremberg Laws were enacted in Nazi Germany, stripping Jews of their citizenship.
09-16: In 1620, the Mayflower departed from Plymouth, England, carrying the Pilgrims to the New World.
09-17: In 1787, the United States Constitution was signed by delegates at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia.
09-18: In 1851, 'The New York Times' was published for the first time.
09-19: In 1893, New Zealand became the first country to grant all women the right to vote.
09-20: In 1519, Ferdinand Magellan set sail on his historic voyage to circumnavigate the globe.
09-21: In 1937, J.R.R. Tolkien's 'The Hobbit' was published.
09-22: In 1862, President Abraham Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.
09-23: In 1846, the planet Neptune was discovered.
09-24: In 1789, the U.S. Congress passed the Judiciary Act, creating the federal court system and the office of Attorney General.
09-25: In 1513, Spanish explorer Vasco Núñez de Balboa became the first European to see the Pacific Ocean.
09-26: In 1960, the first televised U.S. presidential debate took place between Richard Nixon and John F. Kennedy.
09-27: In 1908, the first Ford Model T was built.
09-28: In 1066, William the Conqueror invaded England, beginning the Norman Conquest.
09-29: In 1982, seven people in the Chicago area died after taking cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules.
09-30: In 1955, actor James Dean was killed in a car crash at the age of 24.
10-01: In 1908, the Ford Model T went on sale to the public.
10-02: In 1967, Thurgood Marshall was sworn in as the first African American Supreme Court justice.
10-03: In 1990, East and West Germany were reunified into a single country.
10-04: In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth.
10-05: In 1962, the first James Bond film, 'Dr. No', premiered in London.
10-06: In 1889, the Moulin Rouge cabaret opened in Paris.
10-07: In 1913, Henry Ford's assembly line started operation, revolutionizing the automobile industry.
10-08: In 1871, the Great Chicago Fire began, destroying a large part of the city.
10-09: In 1888, the Washington Monument officially opened to the public.
10-10: In 1845, the United States Naval Academy opened in Annapolis, Maryland.
10-11: In 1984, Kathryn D. Sullivan became the first American woman to walk in space.
10-12: In 1492, Christopher Columbus made his first landfall in the Americas, on an island in the Bahamas.
10-13: In 1792, the cornerstone of the White House was laid in Washington D.C.
10-14: In 1066, the Battle of Hastings was fought, where William the Conqueror defeated the English army.
10-15: In 1951, the classic sitcom 'I Love Lucy' premiered on television.
10-16: In 1793, Marie Antoinette was executed by guillotine during the French Revolution.
10-17: In 1931, gangster Al Capone was convicted of income tax evasion.
10-18: In 1867, the United States formally took possession of Alaska from Russia.
10-19: In 1781, British General Cornwallis surrendered at Yorktown, Virginia, effectively ending the American Revolutionary War.
10-20: In 1973, the Sydney Opera House was opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
10-21: In 1879, Thomas Edison invented a commercially viable electric light bulb.
10-22: In 1962, the Cuban Missile Crisis began as President John F. Kennedy announced a naval blockade of Cuba.
10-23: In 1941, the Disney animated film 'Dumbo' was released.
10-24: In 1929, 'Black Thursday' marked the beginning of the Wall Street Crash.
10-25: In 1415, the English army, led by Henry V, defeated the French at the Battle of Agincourt.
10-26: In 1881, the famous gunfight at the O.K. Corral took place in Tombstone, Arizona.
10-27: In 1904, the first underground line of the New York City Subway opened.
10-28: In 1886, the Statue of Liberty was dedicated in New York Harbor.
10-29: In 1929, 'Black Tuesday' saw the stock market crash, signaling the start of the Great Depression.
10-30: In 1938, Orson Welles' radio broadcast of 'The War of the Worlds' caused a panic among some listeners.
10-31: In 1517, Martin Luther posted his 95 Theses on the door of a church in Wittenberg, Germany, sparking the Protestant Reformation.
11-01: In 1512, the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, painted by Michelangelo, was first exhibited to the public.
11-02: In 1948, Harry S. Truman was elected U.S. President in a major political upset.
11-03: In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 2, carrying the first living creature, a dog named Laika, into orbit.
11-04: In 1922, British archaeologist Howard Carter discovered the entrance to Tutankhamun's tomb in Egypt.
11-05: In 1605, the Gunpowder Plot to blow up the English Parliament was foiled.
11-06: In 1860, Abraham Lincoln was elected the 16th President of the United States.
11-07: In 1917, the Bolshevik Revolution began in Russia.
11-09: In 1989, the Berlin Wall was opened, leading to the reunification of Germany.
11-10: In 1969, the children's television show 'Sesame Street' premiered.
11-11: In 1918, the armistice was signed that ended the fighting of World War I.
11-12: In 1927, the Holland Tunnel, connecting New Jersey and New York City, opened to traffic.
11-13: In 1982, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial was dedicated in Washington D.C.
11-14: In 1889, journalist Nellie Bly began her record-breaking trip around the world in 72 days.
11-15: In 1777, the Articles of Confederation, the first constitution of the United States, were adopted.
11-16: In 1907, Oklahoma was admitted as the 46th U.S. state.
11-17: In 1869, the Suez Canal opened in Egypt, connecting the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea.
11-18: In 1928, the animated short film 'Steamboat Willie', featuring the debut of Mickey Mouse, was released.
11-19: In 1863, President Abraham Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address.
11-20: In 1945, the Nuremberg trials of Nazi war criminals began.
11-21: In 1877, Thomas Edison announced his invention of the phonograph.
11-22: In 1963, U.S. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
11-23: In 1890, the first jukebox was installed in the Palais Royale Saloon in San Francisco.
11-24: In 1859, Charles Darwin's 'On the Origin of Species' was published.
11-25: In 1940, the cartoon character Woody Woodpecker first appeared in the film 'Knock Knock'.
11-26: In 1789, Thanksgiving was first observed as a national holiday in the United States.
11-27: In 1095, Pope Urban II called for the First Crusade.
11-28: In 1520, Ferdinand Magellan began his passage through the strait that now bears his name.
11-29: In 1972, Atari released the pioneering arcade game 'Pong'.
11-30: In 1872, the first international football match took place between Scotland and England.
12-01: In 1955, Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat to a white man in Montgomery, Alabama, sparking the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
12-02: In 1804, Napoleon Bonaparte was crowned Emperor of the French in Paris.
12-03: In 1967, the first successful human heart transplant was performed by Dr. Christiaan Barnard.
12-04: In 1619, the first English-speaking Thanksgiving in America was held in Virginia.
12-05: In 1933, Prohibition in the United States was repealed with the ratification of the 21st Amendment.
12-06: In 1877, 'The Washington Post' newspaper was published for the first time.
12-07: In 1941, the Imperial Japanese Navy launched a surprise attack on the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor.
12-08: In 1980, musician John Lennon was assassinated in New York City.
12-09: In 1907, the first Christmas Seal campaign was launched to fight tuberculosis.
12-10: In 1901, the first Nobel Prizes were awarded.
12-11: In 1936, King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom abdicated the throne to marry Wallis Simpson.
12-12: In 1901, Guglielmo Marconi received the first transatlantic radio signal.
12-13: In 1642, Dutch explorer Abel Tasman became the first European to sight New Zealand.
12-14: In 1911, Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen and his team became the first people to reach the South Pole.
12-15: In 1791, the United States Bill of Rights was ratified.
12-16: In 1773, the Boston Tea Party took place as American colonists protested British taxation.
12-17: In 1903, the Wright brothers made their first successful powered airplane flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
12-18: In 1865, the 13th Amendment, abolishing slavery, was officially adopted into the U.S. Constitution.
12-19: In 1777, George Washington's Continental Army began its winter encampment at Valley Forge.
12-20: In 1803, the Louisiana Purchase was completed, doubling the size of the United States.
12-21: In 1937, the first full-length animated feature film, Disney's 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs', premiered.
12-22: In 1882, the first string of electric Christmas tree lights was created by an associate of Thomas Edison.
12-23: In 1947, the transistor was first demonstrated at Bell Laboratories.
12-24: In 1814, the Treaty of Ghent was signed, officially ending the War of 1812.
12-25: In 800 AD, Charlemagne was crowned Holy Roman Emperor in Rome.
12-26: In 1776, George Washington crossed the Delaware River for a surprise attack on Hessian forces.
12-27: In 1831, Charles Darwin set out on his voyage aboard the HMS Beagle.
12-28: In 1895, the Lumière brothers held the first public screening of a motion picture.
12-29: In 1890, the Wounded Knee Massacre occurred in South Dakota.
12-30: In 1922, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was officially formed.
12-31: In 1879, Thomas Edison gave the first public demonstration of his incandescent light bulb.
